Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A behavioral and computational investigation of the generality and transferability of category representations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
How people acquire and use different types of knowledge is a fundamental issue in cognitive science, applicable to problems in education, training, and the development of expertise. For example, learning to categorize types of materials (such as natural vs. synthetic, or polymers vs. ceramics) can be accomplished using textbooks, but it can also be accomplished with hands on experience in the field. Different types of training likely lead to different forms of knowledge, and the form of knowledge may constrain how, and in what situations, the knowledge can be used. Thus, the best way to train a person may differ depending not only on the type of information being learned, but also on the situations in which the knowledge will need to be used. The investigators will examine how to promote the learning of different forms of knowledge in different situations. They will also investigate the neural and computational bases of the differences in forms of knowledge in order to develop a unifying theory of how knowledge acquisition and application varies across situations in predictable ways. A larger goal is to determine how knowledge, once learned, can be transferred to new situations. This project will advance scientific understanding of human knowledge acquisition and its use. The project also has the potential to foster the development of new tools that may improve the training of students and professionals.

Categorization researchers have made an enormous contribution to the understanding of the many ways in which knowledge can be represented and used. A current challenge facing the field of categorization, and cognitive science more generally, is how to best integrate these findings with the broader goal of understanding the extent to which different types of knowledge representations generalize to new situations. The proposed research utilizes a combination of behavioral, neuroimaging, and computational modeling techniques to address these challenges. Specifically, the investigators will explore (1) the factors influencing the development of different types of category representations, (2) the psychological functions and brain networks supporting category representations, and (3) the utility of different types of category representations for supporting performance in new tasks and/or with new stimuli. In addition, this research will highlight important relationships between machine learning techniques and methods used in cognitive science. As a result, the research should be of broad interest to psychologists, computer scientists, and the general cognitive science community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The way in which people learn and use different types of knowledge is a fundamental issue in the behavioral sciences. For example, learning about plants and trees can be done using textbooks, but it can also be done in the field. These two types of training likely lead to different types of knowledge, and the type of knowledge may constrain how, and in what situations, the knowledge can be used. This project explored how to promote the learning of different types of knowledge and, importantly, how the use of different types of knowledge transfer in new situations. The goal of this project was to advance scientific understanding of a fundamental ability as well as potentially foster the development of new tools that may improve the training of students and professionals.

 

Categorization researchers have made an enormous contribution to the understanding of the many ways in which knowledge can be represented. A current challenge facing the field of categorization, and cognitive science more generally, is how best to integrate these findings and, importantly, understand the generalizability of different types of knowledge representations. This project utilized a combination of behavioral, neuroimaging, and computational modeling techniques to address these challenges. Specifically, the investigator explored (1) the factors influencing the development of different types of category representations; (2) the psychological functions and brain networks supporting category representations; and (3) the utility of different types of category representations for supporting performance in new tasks and/or with new stimuli. In addition, this research highlighted important relationships between machine learning techniques and paradigms used in cognitive psychology. As a result, this should be of broad interest to psychologists, computer scientists, and the general cognitive science community.

During the project period, 10 peer-reviewed journal articles have been published, 12 presentations have been made in peer-reviewed regional and international scientific conferences, and 7 invited oral presentations have been given in scientific conferences and academic institutions. This broad diffusion of the results shows high interest from the scientific community. More specifically, the project resulted in a neuroscientific theory of how verbal rules can be learned and applied, how brain activity is affected by degraded viewing conditions, and how this activity changes as people practice applying these rules. The project also shows that training students in a task that can be easily verbalizable (e.g., categorizing objects as “square” or “triangle”) can result in a different psychological representation than training participants in a task that is not easily verbalizable (e.g., categorizing a medical image as “tumor” or “healthy”). However, this possible difference depends on the way the material is presented. For example, asking students to choose between two categories will affect the psychological representation for verbal categories, but not for non-verbal categories. The type of psychological representations that is learned, in turns, will affect how the knowledge can be applied to new stimuli and categories. For example, learning object features that differ between the categories will generalize well to new objects, but not new categories. In contrast, learning object features that are common among category members will generalize well to new categories, but not new objects. These findings have important consequences on the way we train students and professional depending on whether the learned skills are verbal or non-verbal, and how we would like them to generalize their knowledge.
